narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not very much; this course was a real let-down. Cool projects, but not well-facilitated by the clinic framework.
Packaging solutions in CPG companies Interaction with a real-life client Team dynamics
environmental consulting, manage relationship with client, conduct interviews, desktop research, project management, public speaking
None

I learned how to interpret LCAs, built a deeper understanding of the issues CSR professionals face, and learned the importance of clarifying (and re-clarifying) the project scope as early and often as possible.
I learned how to work with a client on a serious and time sensitive project.
How to manage a project and industry expertise on your project theme.
Critical thinking
Consulting. Great client
I learned a considerable amount about corporate renewable energy procurement. I also gained helpful experience interacting with a client on a long term project.
I got that chance to work with a client that I would not otherwise have.
Real life consulting work

Well
The class did align with my expectations. However, the interaction with the client has frustrating sometimes.
highly aligned

This aligned fairly closely with what I expected. I found Maureen's guidance helpful, though I wish it could have been more structured - we were often unsure how best to use her time.
I learned a lot from working with a specific client and was able to learn more about a space that I knew little about.
It was more engagement than I imagined going into the class.
Learned a lot about business

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - caliber and diversity of project offerings. Some really cool opportunities to engage with dynamic environmental consulting scenarios and a real client. Weaknesses - poor instruction: a couple of interesting guest lectures, but the initial series of lectures on consulting felt like a waste of time. Additionally, while simplicity is certainly an asset, the rigidity around trying to dumb things down to the easy-read format missed the heart of the objective, instead becoming silly busywork.
Cant think of any
S: real-life project; exposure to real client W: Goal changed a lot during the semester

Strength: Overall the class is great. I get hands-on experience with a famous company, good for career development, clear feedback from instructor and teammates Weakness: perhaps the instructor can be a bit less "hands-off" during the semester by somehow checking in with the client to make sure that the project is on the right track. Sometimes it is hard for students to get direct/clear feedback from clients despite the weekly Skype meetings. Also it can be difficult for students to express some ideas directly to clients (say, too much work for a semester, too many changes of research topics, etc.). Instructor can be the ideal liasion.

Strengths: nice client selection with clear expectations. The course's timeline and expectations were super clear and consistent from the beginning. Weaknesses: I think the course would have been stronger if it had been more centered on the project rather than lectures and guest speakers. I absolutely appreciated the opportunity to hear from guest speakers and learn from Maureen's expertise, but I joined the course to work on the project. I think the lectures and guest speakers should be optional - perhaps students should have to attend 5 over the course of the semester, and they can choose the 5 that are most relevant to their project and their professional interests.
The instructor is incredibly poor in providing reasonable feedback, listening to critique, and providing the tools necessary to succeed.

Strengths: Working with a real-world client to develop a useful deliverable is both enriching and rewarding. Engaging guest visits with industry experts were fun and informative. Weaknesses: In-class lectures about consulting were not helpful.

The feedback from Maureen was sometimes conflicting with what the client wanted. Also the editing she provided did not conform to modern standards. It would have been better to have in-line citations, etc.

I enjoyed most of the guest lectures. It would be helpful if we could discuss more as a class at the beginning of the semester strategies for working with the client to get more specific about their goals and expectations (and aligning those with the goals of the Yale team).
Course format should be updated - needs more practical training lessons in communications, data visualization, slide deck creation, etc.
a great course the way it is

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Don't take it - you're better off with a self-guided independent study. The structure of the class is not a value-add.
Its a bit like CEMS 2.0
Be open to change the final objective several times during the semester. Be flexible.
Prioritize the client and talk openly about team dynamics at the outset!
It's a good way to get your capstone credit.

If one of the projects is interesting to you then pursue it. I wouldn't recommend getting involved with a project that isn't personally interesting because it is a long and close engagement with the client.
Be prepared to work hard and be a team player.

The quality of the client project and the enjoyment of the course very much depend on the relationships you have with your group mates because you all work so closely together for the entire semester.
There are plenty of other clinic-based courses that are more useful.
be ready to work hard
